executive_summary: Over the five years to 2022, the Combine Harvester Manufacturing industry's revenue is expected to grow an annualized 5.9% to $3.8 billion, which includes an anticipated 2.9% decline in 2022 alone. In spite of some negative trends during the period, the industry was able to ultimately see growth due to gains made prior to the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic in 2020 due to improving technology driving demand for industry products. A combine harvester is a piece of farm machinery that performs the tasks of harvesting, threshing and cleaning field crops; end users include primarily those who harvest corn, soybeans, wheat, cotton and tobacco. While the industry has increased revenue over the five years to 2022, industry profitability is expected to weaken amid poor demand conditions and increased input costs including the cost of steel and industry wages.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Agricultural prices have been rising, with the agricultural price index increasing an annualized 1.4% over the five years to 2022. This index includes price increases in key downstream markets such as corn, wheat, and soybean production. These three agricultural markets account for a combined 93.4% of industry revenue in 2022, demonstrating how this industry is highly susceptible to swings in demand based on global supply and demand conditions in these commodities markets.

The trade-weighted index, which measures the relative strength of the US dollar against currencies of its major trading partners, increased an annualized 0.5% over the five years to 2022. As a result, foreign manufacturers of combines have been able to sell industry goods at discounted prices relative to domestically produced goods, dampening industry exports. However, the impact of the pandemic on supply chains had a stronger effect on industry trade, causing both industry exports and imports to decline in 2020 for the first year of the period.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: According to the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA), farm incomes have rose since 2017. As agricultural prices are expected to fall slightly over the five years to 2027, this trend could slow or reverse, hurting demand for industry products. Moreover, rising interest rates will likely dissuade some farmers from taking on more debt should they need a new combine harvester, perhaps choosing instead to repair, hurting industry revenue.

Technological innovations in agricultural equipment are expected to improve future farm productivity. For example, GPS technology that enables farmers to optimize land use by avoiding over or underplanting is becoming a common addition to new tractors. This technology can also use computer software to measure crop yields more precisely and is expected to give US farmers an edge in an increasingly competitive global market for agricultural commodities. The integration of new technology into industry products is a critical selling point for farmers who do have the funds to purchase.

industry_definition: This industry manufactures combine harvesters. Combines, also known as threshers, combine the tasks of harvesting, threshing and cleaning grain crops. They are primarily used in the harvesting of field crops, but also small fruits and other food crops. This industry excludes hay and straw combine harvesters.

positive_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level high - steady

key_trends: The number of agricultural operators is weakening
Declining imports have been a function of falling demand across the agricultural sector
Technological innovations are expected to improve future farm productivity
The industry profit margin is expected to remain mostly unchanged

market_segmentation.segment_description: Manufacturers sell directly to retail stores that have consolidated supply chains, eliminating middlemen.
Exports to emerging economies in Asia and Latin America where agricultural output is increasing.
Wholesalers purchase machinery for resale to smaller farms. Rental companies provide rental inventory.

products_and_services.product_description: Combine harvesters designed for harvesting corn.
Combine harvesters designed for harvesting wheat.
Combine harvesters designed for harvesting soybeans.
Combine harvesters manufactured for other agricultural farming activities like cotton and tobacco cultivation.

tier_1_suppliers: Steel Rolling & Drawing in the US
Lubricant Oil Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Engine & Turbine Manufacturing in the US
Tractors & Agricultural Machinery Manufacturing in the US
Automobile Steering & Suspension Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_buyers: Hay & Crop Farming in the US
Tractors & Agricultural Machinery Manufacturing in the US
Construction Machinery Manufacturing in the US
Mining, Oil & Gas Machinery Manufacturing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Farmers can purchase farm machinery on credit based on their existing debt and credit availability. Interest rates affect the availability of finance.
Growth in planted crop acreage increases demand for combine harvesters. Greater use of biofuels like ethanol supported corn cultivation demand.
Farmers replace old equipment with technologically superior harvesting machinery. Subcontracting reduces demand for new machines.

international_trade_points.trade_description: US exports of combine harvesters are declining due to an appreciating dollar making goods less affordable globally.
Imports satisfy only 6.2% of US demand as transportation costs offset any manufacturing savings abroad.

business_locations.location_description: The Plains region accounts for 30.8% of industry establishments, being the largest producer of field crops like corn, soybeans and wheat.
The Southeast accounts for 17.5% of establishments, producing almost all US tobacco and cotton.
The Great Lakes region accounts for 16.7% of establishments and about a third of US corn and soybean production.
The West region accounts for 13.5% of establishments, with California being the largest fruit and vegetable producer.
The Southwest accounts for 9.1% of industry establishments.
The Mid-Atlantic region accounts for 6.4% of industry establishments.
The Rocky Mountains region accounts for 5.4% of industry establishments.
New England accounts for 0.6% of industry establishments.

regulations_points.regulation_description: These laws concern equipment maintenance, safety labels, personal protective equipment and barriers from potentially dangerous machines.

The Clean Air Act of 1990 governs air pollution caused by industry operators. The act empowers the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to determine acceptable pollution levels, which are monitored by state agencies. The act enables larger sources of pollution, such as manufacturing plants, to apply for permits to pollute. The permits include information on which pollutants are being released, how much may be released and what steps the source's owner or operator is taking to reduce pollution (including plans to monitor pollution output).

In addition to the Clean Air Act, the industry must comply with the EPA's emission standards for nonroad engine manufacturers. These standards limit engines' output of nitrogen oxide, nitrogen dioxide and carbon monoxide, and vary with horsepower. The latest standards affecting industry operators are new diesel engine exhaust emission standards, collectively known as the Tier 4 rule. These standards currently cover nonroad diesel engines of 75 to 175 horsepower, and require diesel engine manufacturers to develop new engine emission control systems. Future stages of this EPA standard, which will go into effect by 2015, will cover all nonroad diesel engines.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry has high revenue volatility.
The industry has low and steady level of assistance.

factors_decreased_barrier: The industry has low concentration level.

basis_points.basis_description: The industry's leading operators primarily compete on product quality, performance and innovation.
The industry's leading operators primarily compete on efficient production and distribution arrangements.
The industry's leading operators primarily compete on customer service.
Established brand names can also present an important competitive edge to industry operators.

concentration_points.concentration_description: With no more than 35 enterprises operating in this industry, the top three companies generate an estimated 34.1% of total industry revenue.

concentration_points.concentration_title: High R&D, economies of scale, dealer networks
concentration_points.concentration_description: A high level of research and development, large economies of scale, extensive dealer networks and long-standing reputations make it difficult for new entrants.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The profitability (defined as earnings before interest and taxes) of the Combine Harvester Manufacturing industry is expected to decrease over the five years to 2020 due to weak demand. Currently, the average industry profit margin is mentioned as 8.25%.

Profitability for the combine harvester manufacturing industry is estimated to account for 3.1% of industry revenue, down from 3.8% in 2017. Over the five years to 2027, industry profitability is expected to rise to 3.3% as the effects of the COVID-19 (Coronavirus) pandemic continue to recede.

Wage costs, as a percentage of revenue, have decreased over the five years to 2022, falling from 15.3% of industry revenue in 2017 to 11.5% in 2022. Though the total value of wage payments has increased an annualized 0.1% to reach $435.5 million, industry revenue growth has outpaced wage growth, thereby comparatively decreasing wages as a share of revenue. This trend is due to a push to lower wage costs via technological adoption and automation.

Purchases account for the largest share of industry revenue. Especially during the recent supply chain issues, the price of steel has been volatile. Some industry companies have begun to add a raw-material price-fluctuation clause to large contracts that have long-dated delivery periods. They have included this measure to amend the final sales price for any fluctuations of raw material, whether they are positive or negative. Companies can also hedge their exposure by purchasing futures contracts on iron ore and steel metal. IBISWorld estimates raw material purchases, as a percentage of industry revenue, have fallen to 56.9% over the five years to 2022 as a result of industry cost saving measures.

Although industry operators have adopted production-line technologies that reduce the amount of labor required to manufacture a unit, the industry has become less capital intensive, as measured by falling depreciation costs relative to industry revenue, due to rising revenue. Since 2017, depreciation charges have decreased from 2.0% to 1.8% in 2022.
Marketing expenses are expected to account for 0.2% of industry revenue in 2022 and have fallen slightly from 0.3% since 2017.
Rent costs account for any lease or rental payments incurred by industry operators. These costs account for 0.5% of industry revenue in 2022.
Utilities costs account for any and all heat, water and power consumed during industry operations. This figure accounts for 0.6% of industry revenue in 2022 and has remained steady since 2017.

Other expenses include, sales, general and administrative expenses, freight, insurance expenditures and costs associated with environmental compliance. In recent years, compliance costs have risen due to the Environmental Protection Agency's increased scrutiny of manufacturing processes and agricultural machinery emission output. Overall, other costs are expected to account for 25.4% of industry revenue in 2022.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: It appears that the industry is more dependent on capital than it is on labor. Accordingly, a moderate level of capital investment is necessary in this industry.

volatility_points.volatility_description: The Combine Harvester Manufacturing industry has had a high level of revenue volatility over the five years to 2022, with yearly revenue changes averaging 16.2%. Revenue volatility, is enhanced for this industry because of the variability of farmers' seasonal yields and crop prices, which subject to global supply and demand forces and other exogenous factors. Industry operators typically perform better when farmers expect better harvests. Industry revenue volatility has increased in recent years as agricultural prices have rose in 2021, driving demand for industry products.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: One recent development that enables larger combines with higher yields is tank-like treads (as opposed to wheels). Wide treads reduce ground pressure and minimize the combine's impact on the soil surface; this lets harvesting take place in a wider range of ground conditions. New combines also feature improved high-volume rotors and cutters to deal with the tough stalk material produced by today's crop genetics (particularly for corn), as well as enlarged grain-cleaning systems.

Many new combines can automatically adjust their speed to optimize (i.e. make constant) the rate of delivery of the crop load to the rotors. Some do this with the help of GPS systems; these combines automate speed and steering, which reduces operator fatigue and ensures an even feed of crop material. They combine data from GPS receivers with the combine's mechanical feelers to guide the combine and automatically change its ground speed to compensate for variations in crop that are not visible to the operator.

The main steps of combine assembly are metal fabrication, painting, welding, subassembly, main assembly, final inspection and loading. Much of the production line relies on computer technology and hydraulic robot equipment. For example, robots perform precision laser cutting and computer numeric control punching in the metal fabrication step. Painting is also done robotically, and an automated powder coating process paints a combine's parts before they are assembled. The role of human labor increases as a combine gets nearer to completion in its assembly. Workers directly perform the labor or operate the machinery needed for most welding, assembly, quality control and loading. As a result, human labor and oversight are increasingly important as combines grow in size and value along the line.

FAQs.question: Are your sales dependent on the overall health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Demand for combine harvesters is tied most strongly to agricultural prices, which are subject to a wide range of exogenous factors. As the economy picks up steam, rising interest rates will limit demand for industry products due to higher borrowing costs.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one product line or produce a range of goods?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers who operate in a specific space may exhibit higher segment revenue and profitability due to specialization and brand recognition. Manufacturers that produce a wide range of industry products will be subject to less volatility.

FAQs.question: Is your business located in proximity to key end-markets?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers that are situated near key distribution hubs will exhibit reduced shipping and distribution costs, increasing profitability. Manufacturers that are located near key agricultural regions will exhibit higher demand for industry products, boosting sales figures.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices?
FAQs.answer: Volatility in the price of key inputs such as steel makes planning for future production difficult, inhibiting profitability. Manufacturers that enter into long-term supply contracts with input producers will exhibit less volatility, lower purchase costs and higher profitability.

FAQs.question: Has your company been able to reduce wage costs via technological adoption?
FAQs.answer: In general, by automating productive processes, combine harvester manufacturers can reduce wage costs by automating tasks. Wages as a portion of revenue have actually increased, however, only as a result of declines in revenue outpacing declines in wage payments.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging the latest technologies?
FAQs.answer: The latest technologies such as GPS and auto-steering can be integrated into industry products to increase demand and boost sales. Combine harvesters equipped with the latest technologies will sell at a premium.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are upheld?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers that adhere to labor and consumer safety standards will exhibit lower insurance premiums and may exhibit higher profitability. Manufacturers found to be incompliant will be subject to fines and penalties, reducing profitability.

FAQs.question: Is your company prepared to adapt to shifting environmental regulations?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers that take a forward-looking strategy to environmental regulation may be preferred by key customers, boosting sales. Manufacturers found to be incompliant will be subject to fines and penalties, reducing profitability.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit margin compare to those of your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers with higher operating efficiencies will exhibit lower costs of production and wider profit margins. Manufacturers that enter into long-term supply contracts will exhibit lower purchase costs and higher profitability.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected your profit margin recently?
FAQs.answer: Input price volatility can erode profit margins and make planning for future production difficult. Manufacturers can save on purchase costs by entering into long-term supply contracts at locked in rates, thereby reducing volatility and lowering purchase costs.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain product quality? Do you have systems in place to keep standards high and continually updating?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators need to produce consistent quality to boost sales through brand development.

FAQs.question: How much time is invested in research and development? Does your company use the latest technologies? Is innovation or latest technology one of the company's selling points?
FAQs.answer: Research and development enables operators to develop new products and exploit niche markets, thus giving them an edge over competitors.

FAQs.question: How quickly can new technology be adopted? Does your company keep up to date with the latest technology? What are the associated costs?
FAQs.answer: Operators should adopt new technology quickly and make the most of innovations.

FAQs.question: Do you track the prime rate? How will you combat the threat of an increasing prime rate?
FAQs.answer: Many tractors and related machinery products are purchased on credit. When interest rates increase, demand for new products from this industry generally decreases because the cost of financing goes up.

FAQs.question: How do fluctuating steel prices affect your company?
FAQs.answer: As steel prices increase, so do operating costs for combine harvester manufacturers.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor trends in the agricultural price index (API)? How will an increasing index benefit your company? How do you counteract decreases in the API?
FAQs.answer: When prices for agricultural goods increase, farmers' profit margins widen, giving them additional funds to upgrade equipment.
